required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Feeding and Wellness Among Late Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Early Feeding and Wellness Among Late Preterm Infants Born at MacDonald Women's Hospital: A Feasibility Study for a Breastfeeding Intervention

brief_summary.textblock:
1. The first aim of this proposal is to pilot the feasibility of weekly phone monitoring of infant feeding and illness patterns in a socio-economically and racially diverse population. Specifically, the investigators aim to estimate the rate of group loss to follow up from birth to 13 weeks (3 months) of age with weekly phone interview of mothers of late preterm (LPT, gestational age 34 0/7- 36 6/7 weeks gestation) infants.
2. The second aim is to describe breastfeeding and formula feeding practices, and rates of illness and post-discharge hospital care utilization, through age 13 weeks (3 months) among late preterm infants born at MacDonald Women's Hospital. The investigators estimate that the rate of exclusive breastfeeding among LPT infants at 3 months of age is less than the documented rate of 37% for all infants in Cuyahoga County.

detailed_description.textblock: Late preterm infants (LPT, gestational age 34 0/7 - 36 6/7 weeks) are the largest proportion of all preterm (less than 37 weeks gestation) infants. Recent evidence finds an increased risk of early post-discharge morbidity and re-hospitalization among LPT as compared to full term infants, which is linked to breastfeeding, specifically to early lactation failure and decreased breast milk intake. Accurate and inexpensive methods to collect data on rates of breastfeeding and early morbidity among LPT infants are critical to design, implementation and monitoring of effective interventions. This pilot study evaluates the feasibility of weekly phone calling in a racially and socioeconomically diverse population of mothers of LPT infants.

primary_outcome.measure: The primary outcome measure will be the response rate for phone interview, including total calls made and interviews completed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Secondary outcome measures include (1) rates of partial and exclusive breastfeeding each week , and (2) rates of illness, re-hospitalization and preventive health care

intervention.description: Details of feeding and health/sickness will be obtained

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Mothers of singleton LPT (late preterm, gestational age 34 0/7- 36 6/7 completed weeks) infants
Exclusion Criteria:
- Exclusion criteria for mothers include positive maternal drug screen for drug of abuse
- Age < 18 years, or per caregiver discretion mother is not appropriate for study.
- Exclusion criteria for infants include custody under contention, positive screen for maternal drugs of abuse, or major congenital anomaly or congenital infection.

overall_official.affiliation: Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine
